before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"b618n","text":"Preliminary steps","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1jmkb","text":"Purchase or otherwise obtain Osmia lignaria Say (Hymenoptera: Megachilidae) (adults in cocoons) from a supplier near the researcher's location. The Orchard Bee Association provides guidelines for purchasing and obtaining O. lignaria (Orchard Bee Association [2021]. Guidelines for Sustainably Sourcing and Managing Mason Bees. Link: https://www.orchardbee.org/certification-guidelines-1).","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":29,"length":15},{"style":"italic","offset":220,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":333,"length":53}],"data":{}},{"key":"6u010","text":"Check bloom for the desired fruit or nut crop as often as needed to prepare for the release of O. lignaria using release boxes or tubes.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":95,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d18p7","text":"Osmia lignaria requires mud to complete nest construction. description: {"blocks":[{"key":"24gb7","text":"Our protocol was designed to rear Osmia lignaria Say (Hymenoptera: Megachilidae) from immature stages to adult emergence following their natural phenology in northern Utah. Many aspects of the bee's biology can be analyzed using this protocol, including ecology, genetics, microbiome, pathology, toxicology, and pollinator management. An individual bee can be observed as a response to a treatment group, and its development and survival can be measured. The interaction of various stressors can help define synergistic, antagonistic, and additive effects, including acute, sublethal, and chronic treatment responses. Osmia lignaria was used as a model to rear solitary bees in a laboratory setting. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":34,"length":15},{"style":"italic","offset":618,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"8r6f","text":"Deploy corrugated plastic nesting boxes (Artz et al. 2013, 2014) into the orchard before bloom. Place nest blocks with straw inserts or bundles of cardboard tubes with straw inserts into nest boxes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f4e8k","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"5s855","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a8tbu","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"1vqei","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5cm03","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"85p2e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cd5us","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"1dqhr","text":"","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3ut2f","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"cevvk","text":"Nest boxes can be zip-tied to branches of a tree, two per tree, on different branches. Nest boxes should be attached to alternating trees in the orchard. Nest boxes should face south-southeast when placed in the orchard (Artz et al. 2014).","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"13dsh","text":"Bundles of cardboard tubes with straw inserts should be 40-50 per bundle, and two bundles per nest box (80-100 tubes with straw inserts).","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"2":{"type":"citation","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"authors":"Artz DR, Allan MJ, Wardell GI, Pitts-Singer TL","can_edit":true,"date":1362960000,"doi":"https://doi.org/10.1111/icad.12026","guid":"28323ABEC63611EEA8750A58A9FEAC02","journal":"Insect Conservation and Diversity","protocol_guid":"","title":"Nesting site density and distribution affect Osmia lignaria (Hymenoptera: Megachilidae) reproductive success and almond yield in a commercial orchard"}},"3":{"type":"citation","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"align":"","authors":"Artz DR, Allan MJ, Wardell GI, Pitts-Singer TL","can_edit":true,"date":1417392000,"doi":"https://doi.org/10.1603/EC14237","guid":"C0CE170E78384E8899A55C1CC4BB99EE","id":0,"journal":"Journal of Economic Entomology","protocol_guid":"","protocol_id":0,"title":"Influence of nest box color and release sites on Osmia lignaria (Hymenoptera: Megachilidae) reproductive success in a commercial almond orchard"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"59cdk","text":"Once bloom has begun, place release boxes or release tubes containing cocoons into the orchard on trees that do not have nest boxes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"21mi4","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"fvh3k","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eq6a9","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"22u9o","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6a7lm","text":"Release boxes should fit snugly at the base of where branches come out of the trunk, while release tubes can be secured on branches with zip ties.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6rqu7","text":"Approximately 250 nesting females per acre is sufficient to pollinate apples, and 300 nesting females per acre is sufficient to pollinate almonds. Potential dispersal and mortality of pre-nesting females should be considered for final release numbers. If using loose cocoons, 40-50% more females should be for release. The number of males released should be 1.5 to 2 times more than the number of females.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2p9to","text":"Bosch J, Kemp WP (2001). How to Manage the Blue Orchard Bee As an Orchard Pollinator, Sustainable Agriculture Network handbook series; bk. 5.","type":"unordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"f5p28","text":"Once O. lignaria cocoons are placed in the orchard for release, check nest blocks or bundles of tubes daily for completed nests.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":5,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"37h4l","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cfe3q","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7ek0f","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bnft3","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"129nn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"dlvsj","text":"Nesting should be checked during the late morning or early afternoon.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"d30c2","text":"If there is a completed nest (signified by a mud plug at the entrance of the straw), remove the completed nest by pulling the straw insert with hemostats. Replace with an empty straw, plugged at one end with black hot glue, to encourage population retention.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"35uj8","text":"Carefully transport completed nests to the laboratory to retrieve provisions and eggs/first instars.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7ab6n","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e04em","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"33g6h","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2lm0k","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"32hc1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"as31t","text":"Avoid dropping or rough handling of nests.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"9qdem","text":"Orient nests with the plugged entrance (mud) facing upward during transportation to avoid injuring or dislodging eggs and/or first instars from provisions.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"37eh","text":"Continue checking for completed nests daily, and processing nests until the ideal amount of provisions and sample size (eggs/first instars) is obtained for the experiment.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aje2m","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"ces63","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2n3uq","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"f2n68","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":97},{"key":1,"length":1,"offset":209}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ah6cp","text":"The researcher can continue to check for nests until the end of bloom. Unused nests no more than   old can be retained and used if more than one grafting event is required for the experiment. {"blocks":[{"key":"5g85s","text":"Take a completed nest and shallowly cut along the straw laterally with a single-edge razor blade. Using size 7 insect pins, pin the nest open against an insect pinning board (or foamboard, or hard-backed item). This serves to secure the straw while retrieving provisions and eggs/first instars.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"94p46","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4tcf0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"93doc","text":"To avoid injuring eggs/first instars, do not dig razor blades too deep into the nest while cutting it open. ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"6":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":94},{"key":1,"length":1,"offset":131}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"c1nr0","text":"If any eggs/first instars remain and are no longer needed for the experiment, place them in a   microcentrifuge tube and freeze at   if desired for molecular analyses.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"amount":"1.7","error":false,"guid":"811C7F26C06B11EE919A0A58A9FEAC02","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":2},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"amount"},"1":{"data":{"amount":"1.7","error":false,"error_temperature":false,"guid":"811C7FE3C06B11EE919A0A58A9FEAC02","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"-80","unit":10},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"temperature"}}}},"7":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"5bqau","text":"Use eggs/first instars collected on the provision homogenization date. If the weight exceeds  , remove provision from the bottom side of the straw.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"amount":"0.35","error":false,"guid":"","id":0,"label":"- 0.01 g","scientificNotation":false,"unit":6},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"amount"},"1":{"data":{"amount":"0.35","error":false,"guid":"","id":0,"label":"+ 0.01 g","scientificNotation":false,"unit":6},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"amount"},"2":{"data":{"amount":"0.35","error":false,"guid":"","id":0,"label":"+ 0.01 g","scientificNotation":false,"unit":6},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"amount"}}}},"4":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4sn1n","text":"Plate one treatment group at a time for all well plates. {"blocks":[{"key":"5f4fc","text":"Using the stainless steel grafting tool dipped in Ringer’s Solution, gently pick up an egg/first instar from the 2% agarose gel inside the large Petri dish to transfer onto a treated provision inside a well. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bjcv0","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"78laa","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":257}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"9jehn","text":"Perform this step on the same day as treatment administration. Ringer’s Solution can be placed into wells of a spot plate (use one well per treatment group to avoid cross-contamination) or aliquoted into   microcentrifuge tubes (use one tube per treatment group to avoid cross-contamination). If the researcher does not have enough stainless steel grafting tools to have one per treatment, sterilize the tool between treatments using flame sterilization.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"amount":"1.7","error":false,"guid":"","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":2},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"amount"}}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4eb91","text":"Gently deposit the eggs/first instars onto homogenized treated provisions using the stainless steel grafting tool.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"92b7l","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3g5fd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":629},{"key":1,"length":1,"offset":634}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8n95g","text":"Once eggs/first instars are grafted onto treated provisions in the designated wells, use a dissection microscope to check for damaged eggs/first instars. If eggs/first instars are damaged, regraft immediately with leftover eggs/first instars. Damaged eggs/first instars will look dull (less glossy, Fig. 8) compared to undamaged ones (Fig. 3). Some damaged eggs/first instars may deflate over the next few days if not noticeable on the graft date (Fig. 8). If the researcher questions the current state of the egg/first instar, it is advisable to regraft immediately to maximize the desired sample size. This step is possible if the researcher can access a specimen radiography system with a digital imager.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"4":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"dbtqj","text":"X-rays can be performed until August 1 if the adult molt date is not desired, or X-rays can continue until September 1 if the adult molt date is desired.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"5":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ermte","text":"If the researcher wants a clearer X-ray image of the developing bee, the cocoon can be pulled from the straw liner by gently pulling it with hemostats at the nipple (apical end of the cocoon). If the researcher decides to remove frass, take caution and; then be gentle with the cocoon not to harm the developing bee inside.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"6":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"epiq8","text":"Once a sample on the sticky board leaves the experiment, it creates a blank space on the X-ray. Place an empty gelatin capsule in a pulled sample's place to avoid shifting from its original space.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"7":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":82}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"fvvsg","text":"On August 1 of the study year, if bees have not pupated, they should be frozen at   as it is unlikely those bees will survive. Open by slicing off the apical end of the cocoon (nipple) with a single-edge razor blade, dissecting scissors, or scalpel blade (#5 or 7). Take the razor blade edge and slice away from the developing prepupae, starting where the nipple is sliced off, to open the side of the cocoon. Pull the cocoon open after cutting, not harming the prepupa inside. Use a new blade for each sample or flame sterilize between samples. Use forceps to retrieve the bee and sterilize between samples.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"6D44BB949EB811EE931C0A58A9FEAC02","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"-80","unit":10},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"temperature"}}}},"8":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"guid":"8CB54FE1C77911EEB7180A58A9FEAC02","height":472.43636363636364,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"8gpcp\",\"text\":\"Figure 15. {"blocks":[{"key":"67a4b","text":"After performing the X-ray in Step 28, weigh cocoons without frass to obtain a pre-winter diapause weight in grams (milligrams are also acceptable).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1qrem","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"43ucn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"amb52","text":"Use weigh paper cut into quarters (4x4 in paper cut to approximately 2x2 in sizes) and change between each sample.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"ftjea","text":"Ramp-down conditions for diapause induction: On September 23 of the study year, place box containing sticky boards and a data logger into an incubator programmed at   with   for one week.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":45}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":165,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":172,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"fh0o2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5sakt","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"aqpl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"15","unit":10}},"1":{"type":"humidity","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"50","guid":"","id":0}},"2":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"asfcb","text":"A plastic container with RO water can be placed at the bottom of the incubator to aid in humidity.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6kokt","text":"On February 26 or 27, the following spring, perform an X-ray on the winter diapause sticky boards before obtaining a post-winter diapause weight.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5dmi6","text":"After obtaining the post-winter diapause weight, place cocoons into sterile glass scintillation vials without lids (one cocoon per vial). Label vials with the sample identifier and plug with a cotton ball.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2t3p4","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"2n237","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":11,"offset":56,"style":"italic"}],"key":"8jc3s","text":"We recommend emerging bees in glass vials because adult O. lignaria may chew out of the gelatin capsules if not retrieved immediately. Once the cocoon is inside the vial, use enough of a cotton ball to plug the opening so that it is snug but not overly packed.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"67vkq","text":"Place vials upright into a container and return to winter diapause conditions until ramp-up conditions.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cgdd8","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"cv7e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"e6bre","text":"More than one container may be needed depending on sample size.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"99tm2","text":"Check samples once a day between 12 PM and nightfall for two weeks (until March 15).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4fip8","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"elvkj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"22ggi","text":"Keep daily checks to a consistent time each day. The emergence period can be extended if desired.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}
